author: jcherry
title: Accelerator, Demo day, VC Capital
description: Projects need to turn ideas into businesses. This requires entrepreneurship support programs aligned with tenets of distributed governance.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a proposal to offer a 12 week accelerator program from proposers who claim to have been doing this for years (though without references provided). At 3/4 of the challenge budget this is an expensive proposal, and there are no details as to how many projects will be supported.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers claim significant experience, however we have not been provided with any links to evidence, nor even the proposers full name so it is not possible to verify. As the success of the project relies on their experience and connections this is a key weakness.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has a clear outline of the content of the 12 week program. No timeline has been set however as to when this would be delivered. The proposal also lack information as to how many projects would be supported. They have mentioned some metrics for success such as external funding received, independent market traction, and increase in general ADA acceptance, however only the first is easily measurable and without a goal set against it, how do we measure whether the project has met its aims?

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal answers exactly what is being asked in the challenge. The problem statement "Projects need to turn ideas into businesses. This requires entrepreneurship support programs aligned with tenets of distributed governance." is identified and the solution well articulated: "A virtual mentor/curriculum accelerator... a guided model for going from idea-to-Scale."

The proposal is scalable and future-proof. Furthermore, this collaboration doesn't need to be limited to Catalyst. In time to come, something like this could be incorporated as part of the Decentralized Consortium Funding model as well (https://thedcf.io/).
f6_assessments.q1:
Needless to say, the plan is amazing and the team is really strong.

Naturally, since this would take up 75% of the entire challenge budget, one has to consider what else could be made possible with that money and whether such large sum is warranted. Initially, after seeing in the comments section that this program would be for about 30 teams, I thought "Could this be scaled down and piloted with, say, 10 teams and 1/3 of the cost?" but since 63% of the budget goes to salaries, scaling it down wouldn't really cut costs that much. It could be that time is ripe for Catalyst to start funding this caliber initiatives. After all, this seems to be a budget for the whole year.

Or perhaps this would work better if done in collaborationg with e.g. EMURGO's Adaverse: https://emurgo.io/blog/emurgo-africa-how-to-apply-for-cardano-accelerator-program-adaverse
f6_assessments.q2:
The actual week-to-week plan didn't give much details of what exactly will be covered. It would be good to see specifics like in e.g. The Design Sprint approach from Google Ventures  (https://www.gv.com/sprint/).

Auditing hinges on what the team decides to report along the way and what is shown during public events like the Catalyst Demo Day. More specific KPIs could have been useful to be able to track the progress and not just the outcomes.

Also in the comments section it is mentioned that "we would invest up to $1.25M for every $375K invested in the accelerator program". This quite significant detail is missing from the actual proposal. It only states "Conscious Venture Partners would like the opportunity to invest in companies graduating from this program."

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is in accordance with the challenge goal and with such a professional approach it can make a large impact for funded proposers.

Its budget is quite high, but given the "package" seems reasonable. 

Rating given 5.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer states his experience and skill which is reasonable and in correlation with the proposal. It would be nice to see some examples of those founded start-ups, possibly linked in profile, just to increase the proposer's credibility. 

Besides that, assuming that the information is real and accurate, we can expect that he will deliver and the proposal will be successfully implemented.

Rating given 5.
f6_assessments.q2:
the metrics are divided into three categories, which I find suitable and reasonable.

As stated above, the budget seems quite high compared to other proposals but is still appropriate to the proposal description.

Mapping the progress will be harder to confirm since it will be in a form of provided lectures, meetings, and making familiar with the concept, so it will be hard to tell at what scale are "clients" actually progressing with relation to the output (meant as they can learn, yet they can not benefit from it, so the success of the proposal will be proven in the final output and analysis).


Rating given 4.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a significant challenge addressed in a manner conforming with the Cardano values of education and research. It is comprehensive, detailed and clearly outlines the objectives.
f6_assessments.q1: Links to external experience repositories were unavailable.The plan itself is well documented and could be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal includes a solid program for auditing. The successful development of the program only serves a syllabus for the actual success in the community it is designed to serve.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is aligned with this challenge and seeks to adopt and merge the Conscious Venture Lab program with Catalyst funded projects. The skills and expertise of the team, their networks with VC's and their established curriculum in the start up space would be provided to Catalyst funded projects. The proposal is global, the delivery of their program is online and they have demonstrated a clear interest in supporting projects that are rooted in ethical delivery.
f6_assessments.q1: The project team is established in Baltimore, USA and has a clear purpose-driven charter and seeks projects that align with that philosopy. The program or curriculum that they are seeking to deliver is 12 weeks long, which they have clearly articulated in the project pitch. The budget for the program is explained clearly with a great deal of the budget allocation going to the wages of the project team (236k out of a total 375k.) Sadly with an investment size such as this there is no risk mitigation or scope/size of how many projects they would be able to support or educate through the program.
f6_assessments.q2:
The project deliverables and objectives are opaque, the number of particpants, and what success looks like at the culmination of the curriculum delivery is not specifically quantified. However, there is mention of the overall goals of the project - so seeking to ensure that there are catalyst funded projects or community projects that become viable venture-backable projects and then become attractive businesses in their own right. They also seek to attract developers to the Cardano platform. 

The timeframes are clear but the specific delivery dates are not, this is not such an issue but a project of this size in investment would do well with additional information pertaining to their marketing strategy and how much time they would need in the lead up to the program roll out and indeed if there is flexibility in the delivery timeframe due to much of the program being available online, is it therefor self paced?

f6_assessments.q0: * The proposal identifies a problem within the challenge which needs to be solved. The solution, a replicable and scalable acceleration process for the Catalyst community. is able to scale to address future challenges. Funding outside Catalyst, independent market traction are two huge topics what many funded projects need to improve. The demographic information is wage and could be further elaborated in an updated version, like: stage, sector, region, business model, etc.
f6_assessments.q1: - The proposer runs an Accelerator program and offers us to apply it to Catalyst. The team mentions evidence, but could provide clear proof (names of people involved, their CVs, accelerated startups, etc.). The proposer knows, the type and number of team members required to implement the proposal. The plan is outlined in a weekly-base. The cost break down are based on packages (Johari window, seminar, demo day) + the cost for staff (budget / role). What could be worked out more detailed in order to fully understand why there is a request for staff plus program expenses plus travel, etc. What is also missing in this stage are potential challenges and risks as well as clear metrics.
f6_assessments.q2: How to attract a world-wide audience beyond & for the 'Catalyst Demo Day'? How much is a 'significant number of projects'? Who does what at what stage and especially why do we need the people + program expenses. In an updated version I would appreciate more insights about the how you do it, and which metrics apply to Catalyst. At the moment I have no clue how many projects can achieve what exactly with the requested funding.

solution: A virtual mentor/curriculum accelerator based on theories of stakeholder capitalism, providing a guided model for going from idea-to-Scale.
experience: 10 years operating award winning accelerator.  Founded 11 startups. Crypto investors since 2014. 2020 Baltimore impact person of the year.
